title-group.article-title: Aberrant dynamic Functional-Structural connectivity coupling of Large-scale brain networks in poststroke motor dysfunction

list-item.p: This study extends current research to the field of temporal dynamics. we investigated the dynamic functional and structural connectivity coupling and its relationship with motor function in subcortical stroke from the perspective of network dynamics.

We identified significant group differences in FC-SC coupling of different states after stroke. The main findings were that stroke patients exhibited disturbances of functional and structural brain networks compared with HCs, as well as reduced state-specific functional-structural coupling. More interestingly, these alterations were especially notable in the severely affected stroke patients.

Dynamic functional-structural coupling analysis may be able to capture key features of behavioral deficits after stroke, thus providing new insights for understanding the underlying neural mechanisms of neurological symptoms and personalized treatment strategies in stroke patients.

sec.title: Background and purpose
sec.p: Stroke may lead to widespread functional and structural reorganization in the brain. Several studies have reported a potential correlation between functional network changes and structural network changes after stroke. However, it is unclear how functional-structural relationships change dynamically over the course of one resting-state fMRI scan in patients following a stroke; furthermore, we know little about their relationships with the severity of motor dysfunction. Therefore, this study aimed to investigate dynamic functional and structural connectivity (FC-SC) coupling and its relationship with motor function in subcortical stroke from the perspective of network dynamics.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging and diffusion tensor imaging were obtained from 39 S patients (19 severe and 20 moderate) and 22 healthy controls (HCs). Brain structural networks were constructed by tracking fiber tracts in diffusion tensor imaging, and structural network topology metrics were calculated using a graph-theoretic approach. Independent component analysis, the sliding window method, and k-means clustering were used to calculate dynamic functional connectivity and to estimate different dynamic connectivity states. The temporal patterns and intergroup differences of FC-SC coupling were analyzed within each state. We also calculated dynamic FC-SC coupling and its relationship with functional network efficiency. In addition, the correlation between FC-SC coupling and the Fugl-Meyer assessment scale was analyzed.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: For SC, stroke patients showed lower global efficiency than HCs (all P < 0.05), and severely affected patients had a higher characteristic path length (P = 0.003). For FC and FC-SC coupling, stroke patients predominantly showed lower local efficiency and reduced FC-SC coupling than HCs in state 2 (all P < 0.05). Furthermore, severely affected patients also showed lower local efficiency (P = 0.031) and reduced FC-SC coupling (P = 0.043) in state 3, which was markedly linked to the severity of motor dysfunction after stroke. In addition, FC-SC coupling was correlated with functional network efficiency in state 2 in moderately affected patients (r = 0.631, P = 0.004) but not significantly in severely affected patients.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Stroke patients show abnormal dynamic FC-SC coupling characteristics, especially in individuals with severe injuries. These findings may contribute to a better understanding of the anatomical functional interactions underlying motor deficits in stroke patients and provide useful information for personalized rehabilitation strategies.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Stroke remains a leading cause of serious long-term disability in older adults (Virani et al., 2020). Studies have shown that>80 % of stroke patients develop poststroke movement disorders (Cramer et al., 2019). The inability to carry out normal activities has a significant impact on the activities of daily living in patients, and also creates a major burden on their families (Thrane et al., 2020). At present, most stroke patients do not fully recover even after medical and rehabilitation interventions (Sue et al., 2022). Standard rehabilitation interventions are usually associated with modest rather than significant improvements in motor function (McGlinchey et al., 2020). This illustrates our limited understanding of the biology of motor dysfunction development and recovery. Therefore, it is highly significant to study the neurological mechanisms underlying stroke-caused motor injury to improve rehabilitation; this may provide a crucial theoretical basis for the early neurological rehabilitation of stroke.

A growing body of research suggests that the human brain can be described as a large-scale complex functional and structural network (Mehraram et al., 2022). Graph-based network approaches provide valuable insights into these functional and structural brain networks and allow us to interpret neuroscientific results from the perspective of network and information processing theory (Zhang et al., 2022). For example, Yin et al. (2014) found that the global efficiency (Eg) of subcortical stroke patients was lower than that of healthy controls (HCs) in a functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study. Studies have also reported increased small-worldness and centrality in key motor network areas after rehabilitation interventions in stroke patients (Laney et al., 2015). In addition to abnormal changes of functional network parameters, stroke patients show changes in structural network properties. For example, Zhang et al. (2017) found that stroke patients exhibited a lower global efficiency compared to healthy controls. Yan et al. (2022) used a graph-theoretical approach to measure changes in the topological properties of cortical structural network and found increased clustering coefficients and mean local efficiency in stroke patients compared to healthy controls. However, current research mainly focuses on single functional or structural network parameters. The interaction between functional and anatomical networks in stroke remains poorly studied. Previous evidence indicates a strong correlation between structural connectivity and functional connectivity across the cerebral cortex (Wang et al.,2015). Structural connectivity imposes anatomical limitations on functional connectivity (Honey et al., 2009), which in turn influences structural connectivity by brain plasticity (Guerra-Carrillo et al., 2014). For example, Hermundstad et al. (2013) showed that several structural properties including the length, number and spatial location of white matter streamlines can be indicated and can be inferred from the strength of FCs between areas at rest and during task performance. Therefore, investigating the functional and structural connectivity (FC-SC) relationships may provide deeper insights into the neural mechanisms underlying behavioral deficits in stroke.

FC-SC coupling analysis is considered to be a more sensitive model for identifying subtle variations in brain activity than any unimodal index (Baum et al., 2020, Ma et al., 2021). Multiple studies have demonstrated that the association between the brain’s functional and structural connectivity play a critical role in the disease process (Wang et al, 2015) and is closely related to impairment (Wang et al., 2021), behavioral deficits (Hirsiger et al., 2016), and cognitive flexibility (Litwińczuk et al., 2022). In a study of FC-SC coupling in stroke, Zhang et al. (2017) found a reduction of FC-SC coupling in stroke patients and that the FC-SC coupling was correlated with the Fugl-Meyer motor function score. This suggests that FC-SC decoupling may reflect the progression of motor dysfunction after stroke. In terms of stroke subgroups, Chen et al. (2021a) investigated the differences of FC-SC coupling in capsular stroke and pontine stroke compared with HCs and found that the FC-SC coupling of the two types of patients was lower than that of HCs. Moreover, FC-SC coupling was lower in capsular stroke than in pontine stroke, thus suggesting that capsular stroke may be associated with more severe injury than pontine stroke.

Of note, the FC-SC coupling studies described above suppose that the functional connectivity between two brain regions remains unchanged during the entire MRI data acquisition process. In fact, it is now widely accepted that FC varies over time (Qin et al., 2021), while SC is relatively stable. Consequently, FC-SC coupling may not exhibit a static relationship over time. For example, some studies have shown that different functional connectivity states correspond to variable levels of structural connectivity throughout the resting period (Liu et al., 2021;2022). The study of dynamic FC-SC coupling over time would be well worth exploring as this would extend our understanding of how function-structure relationships underlie human cognition and behavior. However, no previous study has investigated the temporal properties of FC-SC coupling in stroke patients. Thus, it remains unclear how FC-SC relationships change dynamically over time and if these changes are associated with motor dysfunction in stroke patients.

Therefore, we first explored large-scale structural network patterns in stroke patients. Then, we analyzed time-resolved FC patterns to identify recurrent FC states and tested for between-group differences in FC-SC coupling in each state. Subsequently, we analyzed the association between dynamic FC-SC coupling and functional network efficiency to investigate the support of functional-structural relationships for brain information transmission. In addition, relationships between brain network changes and the Fugl-Meyer assessment scale were investigated to understand whether functional-structural relationships might be potential indicators of motor dysfunction after stroke. Based on evidence from previous studies supporting impaired brain networks in stroke (Bonkhoff et al., 2020, Chen et al., 2021a), we hypothesized that FC-SC coupling and its association with symptom severity are altered in stroke patients in certain dynamic FC states. This may provide important insights for a deeper understanding of the pathophysiological mechanisms of stroke and their relationships to clinical outcomes.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 45 subcortical stroke patients and 30 HCs were recruited. This study was approved by the ethics committee of the local hospital (900th Hospital, Joint Logistic Support Department; reference:2015019). Written informed consent was acquired from each participant. The inclusion criteria for patients were: (1) first-ever ischemic stroke; (2) right-handedness; (3) age 40–75 years; (4) examination time was 1 month after the onset of stroke and; (5) single lesion involvement in the basal ganglia and adjacent regions. The exclusion criteria were: (1) history of psychiatric or neurological diseases; (2) MRI contraindications; (3) other brain abnormalities detected by CT or MRI; (4) modified Fazekas scale for white matter hyperintensity > 1 (Fazekas et al., 1987). All patients received standard physiotherapy in the Neurology Department of the 900th Hospital for the first two weeks after stroke. After discharge, all patients received two weeks of inpatient rehabilitation treatment.

sec.title: Clinical assessments
sec.p: Upper limb motor deficits were quantified using the Fugl-Meyer upper extremity assessment scale (FMA-UE); this scale is widely used in stroke studies (Lee et al., 2021). In addition, a patient's ability to perform daily living was assessed by the modified Barthel index (MBI) (Lee et al., 2022).To test the effect of motor dysfunction on FC-SC coupling, we divided the samples into a subgroup of severely affected patients (FMA-UE score: 0–25) and a subgroup of mild-to-moderately affected patients (FMA-UE score: 26–66). This approach has been employed extensively in previous studies (Woytowicz et al., 2017, Saini et al., 2022).

sec.title: Study design
sec.p:
The flow chart of dynamic functional-structural connectivity (FC-SC) relationship analysis is shown in Fig. 1. This analysis comprised five steps: (A) conducting group independent component analysis on resting-state fMRI data and selecting the signal-related independent components; (B) constructing a structural brain network among ICs; (C) estimating the connectivity of dynamic functional networks and performing clustering analysis; (D) performing graph theoretic network analysis for SC and FC networks, and (E) conducting dynamic FC-SC coupling analysis.Fig. 1
Flow chart of dynamic functional–structural connectivity relationship analysis.

sec.title: MRI acquisition
sec.p: The imaging data were obtained by a 3.0-Tesla scanner (MAGNETOM Trio Tim System, Siemens, Erlangen, Germany) with a 12-channel head coil. For each participant, the following sequences were acquired: (1) one T1-weighted structural scan, (2) one 6-minute resting-state functional MRI scan, and (3) one diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) scan. Three-dimensional T1-weighted magnetization was used to generate fast gradient echo imaging sequences to obtain high-resolution structural images: repetition time (TR) = 1900 ms; echo time (TE) = 2.52 ms; Number of slices = 176; Slice thickness = 1 mm; no gap; Field of view (FOV) = 240 mm × 240 mm; Matrix = 256 × 256. Gradient echo plane imaging sequences were used to acquire functional images: TR = 2000 ms; TE = 21 ms; Number of slices = 33; Slice thickness = 4 mm; gap = 0.8 mm; FOV = 240 mm × 240 mm; Matrix = 64 × 64; 180 volumes; 6-min session. Echo plane imaging sequences based on spin echo were used to obtain DTI data: TR = 7200 ms; TE = 104 ms; Number of slices = 47; Slice thickness = 3.0 mm; no gap; Matrix = 128 × 128; FOV = 256 mm × 256 mm; one volume without diffusion weighting (b = 0 s/mm2) and 64 nonlinear directions (b = 1000 s/mm2); DTI acquisition time was 8 min and 11 s. Participants were asked to remain still, eyes closed, awake, and relaxed during the data collection.

sec.title: Data preprocessing
sec.p: Prior to data preprocessing, the lesion images of the left hemisphere were flipped from left to right along the midsagittal line to ensure that the lesions were uniformly located on the right side. This approach has been successfully used by previous researchers (Bonkhoff et al., 2020, Liu et al., 2020).

PANDA1.3.1 software was used to preprocess the DTI data (https://fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslwiki/). First, the DICOM files were converted to NIFTI format. Subsequently, brain masks were estimated, and the original images were cropped. These were corrected for head motion and eddy distortion. Finally, diffusion tensor metrics were calculated, including fractional anisotropy (FA). For DTI processing parameters, we used the default settings of PANDA software.

The DPARSFv4.0 toolbox was used to preprocess the rs-fMRI data (https://www.rfmri.org/dpabi). The main steps included discarding the five initial volumes, temporal layer realignment, head movement correction, normalization to the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space, and spatial smoothing using a Gaussian kernel with a half-peak full width of 6 mm. To reduce the potential impact of head movements on FC, we excluded participants with head movement > 2 mm or rotation > 2° or average frame displacement > 0.5 mm. For this, fourteen participants were excluded due to head motion artifacts, including six stroke patients and eight HCs. Thus, the final sample for further analyses included 39 S patients and 22 HCs.

sec.title: Group independent component analysis
sec.p:
FMRI data were decomposed into multiple independent components using the GIFTv4.0b toolbox (http://mialab.mrn.org/ software/gift/) to identify independent spatial components (ICs). First, participant-specific data were reduced to 120 principal components by applying principal component analysis. Using the expectation maximization algorithm, the participant-reduced data were then concatenated and further decomposed into 100 independent components (Bell & Sejnowski, 1995). The aggregated spatial map was constructed using the Infomax algorithm in ICASSO, and the process was repeated 10 times. Finally, spatial maps and time courses of the subjects were obtained using a spatio-temporal regression inverse reconstruction method with Fisher’s Z transformation. Significant ICs were selected by manual inspection according to the criteria provided by Allen et al. (2014). The selection criteria were: (a) peak located in gray matter; (b) no spatial overlap with vascular, ventricular or cerebrospinal fluid susceptibility artifacts; and (c) time course with predominantly low frequency signal and high dynamic range. The final 39 ICs were determined to be significant. Based on their anatomical and functional properties (Allen et al., 2011; 2014), they were classified into seven resting-state brain networks (RSNs).These RSNs were distributed in subcortical (Sub; 1 IC), visual (VIS; 11 ICs), auditory (AUD; 3 ICs), sensorimotor (SMN; 5 ICs), frontoparietal (FPN; 9 ICs), default mode (DMN; 8 ICs), and cerebellum (CB; 2 IC) networks (Fig. 2A).Fig. 2
Brain connectivity matrix. (A) 39 ICs were identified and grouped into seven resting state networks; (B) the structural connectivity matrix was constructed by extracting the FA mean value of the fiber tracts, and (C) the matrix of group-averaged functional connectivity of the 39 selected ICs in all participants and its conversion to z values with Fisher's z-transformation.

sec.title: Structural brain networks
sec.p: The 39 ICs derived from rs-fMRI data were defined as nodes in the structural brain network. Spatial maps of these ICs in MNI space were transformed into the local DTI space for each participant (Liu et al., 2022). Specifically, a single FA image was linearly transformed to co-register with the b0 image which was then registered to an ICBM152 template by non-linear transformation (Liu et al., 2022). To re-establish edges in the structural brain network, we used deterministic fiber tracking methods based on fiber assignment using the continuous tracking (FACT) algorithm to track white matter fibers between ICs pairs; this is a proven method for reconstructing connectomes (Smith et al., 2020). Here, the termination condition for fiber tracking was set as a turning angle > 45° or an FA value<0.15. Combined with whole white matter fiber tracts and ICs, the mean FA values of all fiber tracts between each two regions were extracted and a 39 × 39 weighted FA network matrix was finally generated (Fig. 2B).

sec.title: Dynamic functional brain networks
sec.p: We used the “temporal dFNC” feature of GIFT package. The sliding window method and cluster analysis were used to calculate dynamic functional connectivity (Allen et al., 2014, Calhoun et al., 2014). Before calculating functional connectivity, additional post-processing was performed on the time course of all components to regress the remaining noise sources. The processing of this step mainly includes: (1) elimination of linear, quadratic and cubic trends; (2) regression of head motion parameters; (3) regression of outliers; and (4) low-pass filtering (cutoff = 0.15 Hz). A tapered window was used to segment the IC time-courses. We chose a window length of 22 TR (44 s); this has been proven to represent an excellent compromise between the capacity to detect functional dynamics and the quality of correlation matrix estimation (Allen et al., 2014, Malhi et al., 2019). For each window, the functional connectivity between ICs was estimated using a regularized inverse covariance matrix; in this analysis, a penalty was imposed on the L1 norm in the LASSO graphical framework to promote sparsity of the estimates. Finally, Fisher's z-transformation was applied to all FC matrices to improve the normality of the correlation distribution. The k-means unsupervised clustering algorithm was employed with the squared Euclidian distance metric to identify recurrent patterns (i.e., states) of FC. All participants windowed FNC matrices were concatenated and input to the k-means algorithm (500 iterations and 150 replicates) (Malhi et al., 2019). The elbow criterion was employed to evaluate the optimal number of clusters as 4 (k = 4); this was computed as the ratio of the inter-cluster distance to the intra-cluster distance (Bonkhoff et al., 2020).

sec.title: The graph-theoretical properties of structural networks
sec.p: The GRETNA2.0 toolbox was applied to compute the graph-theoretic properties of anatomical brain networks. We applied the values of the matrix elements (the threshold sequence was set to 0) to the structural matrix. Seven parameters were used to characterize the global network architecture of the structural brain networks, including the normalized clustering coefficient (γ), normalized characteristic path length (λ), clustering coefficient (Cp), characteristic path length (Lp), small world, global efficiency (Eg) and local efficiency (Eloc). The area under the curve (AUC) was used for statistical analysis (Watson et al., 2019, Chen et al., 2022).

sec.title: Dynamical functional network efficiency
sec.p: To study the capability of parallel information processing and transmission in functionally connected networks, we calculated the network efficiency for each participant in each dynamic state, including Eg and Eloc. A sparsity threshold (S) was applied to connectivity matrices. Because the selection of the sparsity value is known to affect the measurement of topological properties, we set the sparsity threshold from 0.1 to 0.35 with a step of 0.01 (Liu et al., 2022). To avoid choosing a specific threshold, the AUC method was applied to measure topological characteristics; this method is widely used in network research based on graph theory (Wang et al., 2020).

sec.title: FC-SC coupling analysis
sec.p: The methodology used for FC-SC coupling analysis in this study has been reported in several previous studies (Ma et al., 2021, Chen et al., 2022). For the functional-structural network coupling analysis, the non-zero elements in the structural connectivity matrix of each participant were first extracted; and these non-zero elements constituted the structural connectivity vector. The functional connectivity corresponding to the positions of the non-zero elements in the structural connectivity matrix were also extracted; these functional connectivity strengths constituted the functional connection vector. Then, Pearson correlation coefficients of functional connectivity and structural connectivity vectors were calculated for each dynamic FC state. The correlation coefficients were the coupling values for the functional and structural connectivity network.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The SPSS statistical package version 22 (SPSS, Corp, Armonk, NY) was used to analyze data. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to analyze the differences in demographic information among the three groups. Independent sample t-test was used to analyze differences in clinical measurement data between subgroups. Significance was set to P < 0.05.

For each network indicator of SC and FC, the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test was used to evaluate the normality of the data. If the data were not normally distributed, the Kruskal-Wallis H rank sum test was used. If the data were normally distributed and variance homogeneity existed, we used analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) to analyze between-group differences in SC and FC network indicators with sex, age, and education level as covariates. For structural network topology, functional network topology, and FC-SC coupling analysis showing significant differences, Bonferroni corrected post-hoc comparisons were performed (P < 0.05). To determine the relationship between FC-SC coupling and dynamic network efficiency and clinicall assessments in stroke patients, we used Pearson's partial correlation analysis controlling for the effects of sex, age, and education level. P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Demographic characteristics and clinical symptoms
sec.p:
A total of 19 severely affected patients (11 males; mean age, 54.41 ± 4.43 years), 20 moderately affected patients (14 males; mean age, 59.26 ± 4.81 years), and 22 HCs (13 males; mean age, 56.57 ± 4.13 years) were included. There were no significant differences in terms of age, sex and educational level when compared between all stroke patients and HCs. In the subgroups analysis, we found that the FMA-UE (P < 0.001) and MBI (P = 0.002) were significantly reduced in the severely affected subgroup when compared to that in the moderately affected subgroup. In contrast, there was no significant difference between the two subgroups in terms of age, sex, educational level, and lesion location (Table 1).Table 1

sec.title: Structural network analysis
sec.p:
Both the severely affected subgroup (P = 0.007) and moderately affected subgroup (P = 0.025) showed lower levels of global efficiency compared with HCs. Furthermore, Lp values for severely affected patients were markedly higher than those in HCs (P = 0.003). In addition, no significant differences were identified between the severely affected subgroup, the moderately affected subgroup and HCs in terms of the other structural network parameters (Fig. 3, Supplementary Table 1).Fig. 3
Between group differences in topological properties of large-scale structural connectomes. Differences were assessed between severely and moderately affected stroke patients and healthy participants.

sec.title: Dynamic functional network efficiency
sec.p:
The dynamic FNC data of all participants were used to identify-four recurrent connectivity states using the k-means clustering method; the cluster centroid for each state is shown in Fig. 4A. First, we explored the Eloc and Eg of all participants in each state and then compared these data between groups. We found that the Eloc of state 2 in the severely affected subgroup (P = 0.038) and moderately affected subgroup (P = 0.049) was significantly lower than that in HCs (Fig. 4B, Supplementary Tables 2,3). Furthermore, the severely affected subgroup showed lower Eloc in state 3 (P = 0.031) than that in HCs. In addition, there was no significant difference between the severely affected subgroup, moderately affected subgroup and HCs in terms of their dynamic Eg (Fig. 4C).Fig. 4
Dynamic FC cluster centroids, state-wise network efficiency and FC-SC coupling strength. (A) cluster centroids for each functional connectivity state; (B) State-wise distributions and between-group differences of local efficiency; (C) State-wise distributions and between-group differences of global efficiency, and (D) Distributions and between-group differences of FC-SC coupling strength.

sec.title: Dynamic SC-FC coupling
sec.p: Compared with HCs, the severely affected subgroup (P = 0.030) and moderately affected subgroup (P = 0.036) showed reduced FC-SC coupling in state 2. More importantly, FC-SC coupling in state 3 was markedly reduced in the severely affected subgroup when compared to the HCs group (P = 0.043, Fig. 4D). In addition, there was no significant difference between the severely affected subgroup, moderately affected subgroup, and HCs in other states.

sec.title: The relationship between FC-SC coupling and functional network efficiency
sec.p:
This study assessed the correlation between dynamic network efficiency with marked between-group differences and FC-SC coupling in each state. The FC-SC coupling and Eloc were significantly correlated in state 2 in moderately affected patients (r = 0.631, p = 0.004), but not significantly in severely affected patients (Fig. 5A).Fig. 5
(A) Relationship between the efficiency of dynamic functional networks and FC-SC coupling characteristics; (B) correlation between FC-SC coupling characteristics and clinical variables.

sec.title: Clinical correlates
sec.p: Finally, we evaluated whether FC-SC coupling values with marked between-group differences were associated with clinical variables. In this study, we found a positive correlation between FC-SC coupling and FMA-UE scores in severely affected patients in both state 2 (r = 0.534, P = 0.022) and state 3 (r = 0.549, P = 0.018), but no significant correlation between FC-SC coupling and FMA-UE score was found in moderately affected patients (Fig. 5B). In addition, we found no association between the MBI and abnormal FC-SC coupling.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We investigated the neuropathology of stroke from the perspective of dynamic functional-structural connectivity coupling. Our main findings were that stroke patients exhibited disturbances of functional and structural network efficiency compared with HCs, as well as reduced state-specific FC-SC coupling. More interestingly, these alterations were especially notable in the severely affected stroke patients. Our findings provide new insights into investigating the severity of post-stroke injury and the mechanisms of functional and structural network alterations associated with stroke injury.

Both functional and structural brain systems can be described as complex networks; they are optimally balanced between global efficiency and local specialization, which can be measured using graph theoretical metrics such as Eg, Eloc, and Lp (Wang et al., 2014). This phenomenon has been demonstrated in healthy individuals (Bullmore and Sporns, 2009, Shah et al., 2018) and has been shown to be disturbed in various neuropsychiatric states such as stroke (Yin et al., 2014), depression (Yun and Kim, 2021), Autism spectrum disorder (Cai et al., 2022), and Alzheimer's disease (Lo et al., 2010). The present study found reduced Eg in stroke patients. Eg reflects the ability to integrate information at the global level of structural brain networks. Based on the theoretical basis of global efficiency measures, this finding may suggest a reduced capacity for information transmission. This is consistent with previous studies. For example, Zhang et al. (2017) reported significantly lower Eg in stroke patients. In contrast, the Eloc of the post-stroke structural network was not significantly different from that of HCs. Local efficiency measures the ability to transmit information in local areas within a network, and also reflects the ability of the network to defend against random attacks to a certain extent (Rubinov and Sporns, 2010). No significant change in local efficiency of the structural network was found in this study. This may suggest that local efficiency and modular information processing abilities supported by anatomical connections were not impaired, thereby serving a protective role against functional impairment caused by stroke to some extent. Furthermore, we identified an essential increase in the Lp of the structural network in the severely affected subgroup. The Lp is used to reflect the ability to transmit information in the brain (Chen et al., 2022). The shortest paths between distant brain regions ensure the rapid transmission and efficient integration of information (Chen et al., 2021a). The present study observed that the Lp was significantly increased in the structural network of severely affected patients, thus suggesting that the neuronal capacity to integrate information and transmit information over long-distances were reduced in severely affected patients.

FC-SC coupling represents the pairwise relationship between functional and structural networks and has been broadly used to explore changes in the progression of psychiatric or neurological diseases (Gu et al., 2021, Zarkali et al., 2021). The SC provides an underlying foundation for FC; moreover, FC shapes SC through a plasticity mechanism (Honey et al., 2010, Gu et al., 2021). Several studies demonstrated reduced FC-SC coupling in stroke patients by combining structural and functional network analyses (Zhang et al., 2017). This study extends current research to the field of temporal dynamics. We identified significant group differences in FC-SC coupling of different states, predominantly state 2 and state 3. State 2 is mainly characterized by sparse connectivity within and between networks. Previous studies have shown that in many neuropsychiatric diseases, such as Huntington's disease (Espinoza et al., 2019) and subjective cognitive decline (Chen et al., 2021b), patients have significantly increased incidence in the weakly connected state, and that such sparse inter- and intra-network connections may represent brain network damage. This has been similarly studied in stroke. For example, Wang et al. (2020) suggested that the increased frequency of weakly connected state in stroke patients may imply impaired function in patients. However, the present study further found reduced FC-SC coupling in weakly connectivity states in stroke patients, which may suggest further disruption of coherence between brain function and structural connections after brain injury. Interestingly, we found that patients in the severely affected subgroup showed a significant reduction in FC-SC coupling in state 3. State 3 showed stronger connectivity within the respective domains of sensorimotor and cognitive control. FC-SC coupling plays an essential role in the development of higher-order cognitive functions such as attention, working memory, executive function, and cognitive flexibility (Cao et al., 2020, Zhang et al., 2022). Previous studies have shown that the decoupling of these higher-order regions of cognitive control can explain the existence of cognitive deficits (Ma et al., 2021). Here, we cautiously speculate that severe brain region dysfunction may lead to advanced cognitive impairment. Furthermore, we further found that the reduced FC-SC coupling value in state 2 and state 3 was positively associated with a greater motor dysfunction. This finding indicates that diminished structural support relating to functional brain communication may be dominated by different dynamic states, which in turn contribute to varying degrees of behavioral deficits in stroke patients. In a word, these findings may contribute to the understanding of the neural remodeling mechanisms of functional impairment after stroke from a network dynamics perspective.

We also found that patients exhibited lower local efficiency of state-specific functional networks, especially in the severely affected subgroup, thus indicating the overall inefficiency of brain information transmission in stroke patients. We further explored the relationship between network efficiency and FC-SC coupling. Interestingly, the moderately affected subgroup showed a positive association between functional network efficiency and FC-SC coupling in state 2, but this relationship was not significant in severely affected patients, thus indicating that the efficiency of the brain to transmit information in severely impaired subgroups was no longer constrained by structural limitations related to functional brain communication. Tight structural and functional coupling has been shown to support efficient communication between tightly interconnected associated regions within isolated RSNs (Kim et al., 2019, Baum et al., 2020, Nabulsi et al., 2020). Moreover, the high coupling of the FC-SC could diminish competitive interference among different RSNs in order to meet various needs when processing target brain information (Chan et al., 2022). Therefore, the non-significant relationship between functional network efficiency and reduced FC-SC coupling in severely affected patients in state 2 - in contrast to the positive relationship between these measures seen in moderately affected patients - suggests that the relationship between information transmission efficiency throughout the functional brain network and the decoupling of structural–functional connections is sensitive to the severity of clinical impairment in post-stroke. The exact mechanism of this discovery requires further investigation in the future.

Several limitations need to be considered. Firstly, the sample size included in this study was relatively small; consequently, future studies should replicate these investigations in larger cohorts. Secondly, cross-sectional studies are not considered capable of causal inference; therefore, longitudinal designs are now needed to further address the causal relationship between dynamic functional–structural coupling and behavioral relationship at the brain network level. Thirdly, this study used deterministic fiber tracking method to construct structural network, and probabilistic fiber tracking method should be used to construct structural network in the future. Finally, analysis of FC-SC coupling in this study mainly focused on the connections of non-zero structural connectivity but ignored the association between functional connectivity and indirect fiber pathways. Future work should more fully assess the communication capacity of each structural network connection by direct and indirect fiber tracts between each pair of brain regions.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Our findings indicate that dynamic functional-structural coupling is abnormal in stroke patients and that severely affected patients show a more significant reduction in state-specific coupling. Dynamic functional-structural coupling analysis may be able to capture key features of behavioral deficits after stroke, thus providing new insights for understanding the underlying neural mechanisms of neurological symptoms and personalized treatment strategies in stroke patients.
